data.title: The Secret Garden (1987)
data.meta_description: When a spoiled English girl living in 19th century India loses both parents in a cholera epidemic, she is sent back to England to live in a country mansion. The lord is a strange old man-- frail and deformed, immensely kind but so melancholy. She wishes to discover what has caused him so much sorrow and to bring joy back to the household. It all must have something to do with the screams and wails which echo through the house at night and no one wants to talk about.
data.text:
The 1993 film was the first version of The Secret Garden I saw, but fortunately discovered this 1987 version soon after. As a kid, I had both versions on VHS, but this one had plenty more replays and remains my favorite.

All the kids in here are delightful. Gennie James plays Mary as such a little spitfire, but one who comes into her own and matures into a kind young woman. She does better in the role than whoever the random kid from 1993 was. Barret Oliver's been a childhood favorite thanks to The NeverEnding Story and D.A.R.Y.L., even if his Yorkshire accent is practically non-existent here. Dickon's fate in here is different from the book, but it does leaveâ€¦
